Matt Duckor cuts through the wine jargon to tell you what you really want to know: What to buy, when to drink it—and what to say about it at a dinner party.

items.dek: Why should you skip the bottles? Because boxed wine is cheap, good for the environment, and chic (yes, chic).
items.promoHed: 4 Reasons You Should Be Buying Wine in a Box
items.body:
When's the last time you rolled up to a dinner party with a tray of hummus and a box of wine? The answer is probably never. (Well, except for maybe the hummus. [Can we talk about why you're still buying that?](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/recipe-freestyle-hummus-article-article))

But that's all about to change. "The perception that wine is bad because it comes in a box just isn't true anymore," says Meg McNeill, the wine buyer at Brooklyn's [Dandelion Wine](http://dandelionwineshop.tumblr.com). Meg and her staff have been excited about boxed wines for years, and have grown the store's roster of boxed vino to over a dozen selections. Why? Because once McNeill sells a customer on boxed wine, the customer gets hooked. Here's what she tells them.

Boxed Wine is Insanely Cheap
-----------------------------------------------------
Like $8-a-bottle cheap. Prices vary, of course, but most boxes retail in the $30 range for 3L of wine—the equivalent of 4 regular-sized bottles. How can non-swill wine be available for prices like that? "The combined savings that we’re getting on shipping and the producers are getting for not having to package things in bottles are being passed onto you," explains McNeill. 

[#article: /articles/5527ceb920ca5d650ed21912]||||||

Boxed wine lasts longer
----------------------------------------------
We've all opened a bottle of wine for a quick glass, only to come back to the bottle a week later and find it ruined. That will never happen with the boxed stuff. "Wine's biggest enemies are light and air," says McNeill. " Both of those things are negated by the box—no cork, no light pollution." So go ahead and crack open that box even when you just want one glass—the wine will last for about a month.

Boxed Wine is Great for the Environment
-----------------------------------------
It's true! All of those shipping and packaging savings you're getting also reduce carbon emissions. "Take a case of bottled wine that gets shipped to us," says McNeill. "Not only is everything made of glass, but there’s the cardboard box the wine comes in, and all of the paper dividers and filler material to keep the glass from breaking." All that packaging adds up to heavy loads for trucks to carry, which is why [bottles have twice as big a carbon footprint as boxes](http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/18/opinion/18colman.html). 

Boxed wine can be organic and natural
------------------------------------------------------------------------
By now you've no doubt realized that boxed wine has moved beyond the mass-produced Franzia in your grandmother's refrigerator. So, who, exactly, is making all of this cheap, delicious wine? The same producers that make wine in bottles. In fact, "in some cases, the exact same wines are available in bottles," says McNeill. This means you can even find trendy organic and natural wines in boxes. And things are only getting better—the uptick in popularity has caused many wine distributors to approach new wine makers to request that they start putting wines in boxes. 

4 Bottles—er, Boxes—to Try
--------------------------
McNeill loves these boxed options, all of which are available at [Dandelion Wine's](http://dandelionwineshop.tumblr.com/) Greenpoint Brooklyn shop. 

__Fuenteseca Tempranillo 2013__ - $25 "It’s a little spicy, a fuller bodied wine. It’s aged in oak barrels and has a dark, rich berry fruit." Buy it [here](http://thevinecollective.com/wine_site/?p=5015). 

__Maison Cubi Sauvignon Blanc 2014__ - $30 "They’re a sustainable producer who has started focusing on boxed wine. They’ve sought out producers and growers from around France to find the best quality and value possible. A small company run by two french men who are buddies. Super bright, clean, vibrant, and fresh." Buy it [here](https://www.gramercywine.com/wines/Maison-Cubi-Sauvignon-Blanc-w6220325db). 

__Domaine de la Patience "From the Tank" Rosé 2014__ - $38 "This is my favorite of the rosé boxed wine options. From an organic producer. It just has a lot of character and is really pretty exceptional at the price. I was a bar in Brooklyn where they pour it by the glass for $11 and no one thinks twice." Buy it [here](https://thewinefeed.com/shop/domaine-de-la-patience-from-the-tank-rose-3l/#.VUuud2RViko). 

__Domaine de Gabelas Saint Chinian 2013__ - $42 "It’s totally delicious. This is an all-natural, unfiltered wine. It’s wonderful. It’s a little funky and earthy, fresh red fruit." Buy it [here](http://www.naturalwine.com/wine/WIN11839/).
items.seoTitle: Why Boxed Wine Is Worth Buying
items.seoDescription: Boxed wine is cheap, good for the environment, and chic (yes, chic).
items.socialTitle: Why Boxed Wine Is Worth Buying
items.socialDescription: Next time you visit a wine store, think inside the box.

items.hed: 4 Relatively Impressive Things to Say About Slightly Sparkling Wine
items.dek: What's a wine that bubbles more than table wines but less than Champagne? Drinkable.
items.promoHed: Meet the Wines That Sparkle—but Aren't *Sparkling*
items.seoTitle: 4 Relatively Impressive Things to Say About Slightly Sparkling Wine
items.socialTitle: 4 Relatively Impressive Things to Say About Slightly Sparkling Wine
items.body:
"I wouldn't necessarily call this *sparkling*..."
--------------------------------------------------------------
Let's get science-y for a minute. A traditional sparkling wine like Champagne goes through two fermentation processes. The first one goes down in temperature-controlled tanks; the second happens in the bottle, after additional yeast and sugar is added. A critical difference in the production of wines that we're calling "slightly sparkling" (more on other names these wines go by in a minute) is that less sugar and yeast are added during the second fermentation process. That leads to less carbon dioxide, which leads to less pressure, which leads to fewer bubbles, all of which makes for wine with a lower level of carbonation. 

[#package: /packages/551571856ec924e9311cc101]||||||

Still with us? Good, science class is dismissed.

So just what does "slightly sparkling" mean to the average drinker? These wines possess some of the effervescent characteristics of true sparkling wines, but they're closer to beer in carbonation levels. They're also brighter and—dare it be said—more fun than fully sparkling wines. Trust that nobody will be mistaking this stuff for Champagne.

"Almost every wine region has a version of this stuff."
-------------------------------------------------------
Slightly sparkling wines aren't restricted to just one wine region. Maybe you've heard of wines described as *frizzante*? Those are the slightly sparkling wines of Italy. Hop over to France and you'll find bottles of wine described as being made in the *pétillant naturel* ("naturally sparkling") fashion. The hills of Spain's picturesque Basque Country are home to Txakoli, the region's very own high-acid, gently-sparkling wine. 

"These are the easy-drinking beers of the wine world."
-----------------------------------------------
Slightly sparkling wines tend to have a low ABV (Alcohol By Volume), which make them perfect candidates for spring and summer day-drinking. Rather than knocking yourself on your feet by 2PM—or, ahem, 11am—these bottles, which clock in at 10% or 11% ABV, ensure that you'll have something to responsibly sip on throughout the day at your park picnic, beach jaunt, or poolside soirée. 

"Let's leave the bottles on the table."
-------------------------------------------------------------------
There are few better ways to start or end a meal than with a glass of Champagne. But what about in-between? While technically Champagne pairs well with *everything*, the high level of carbonation can be intense for an entire meal. This is not an issue with slightly sparkling wines—the easy, breezy effervescence makes sticking with them through the course of a meal a pleasure. Proof: Lambrusco, which can stand up to a light vegetable dish just as well as a plate of Peking Duck. 

3 Bottles to Buy
---------------
__2013 "Nouveau Nez" Pétillant - $27__ This wine comes from the great-great grandson of legendary French winemaker Alfonse Delecheneau. Produced in France's Loire Valley, this wine brings some crisp citrus fruit to the table and makes for some beautifully balanced drinking. Buy it [here](http://www.astorwines.com/SearchResultsSingle.aspx?p=1&search=30275&searchtype=Contains).

__2014 Txakolina Ameztoi - $20__ This bottle has the power to transport you directly to the rolling hills of Spain's Basque country. A crisp wine with high minerality that's perfect for outdoor drinking on spring or summer days. Want to achieve the same effect, but with pretty-in-pink Rosé? They've [got that too](http://www.astorwines.com/SearchResultsSingle.aspx?p=1&search=19856&searchtype=Contains). Buy it [here](http://www.astorwines.com/SearchResultsSingle.aspx?p=1&search=12280&searchtype=Contains). 

__NV Lini 910 Lambrusco Rosso 'Labrusca' - $15__ This gentle red sparkler from Italy's Emilia-Romagna region is a great rosé-alternative. Give it a slight chill and pair it with everything from light salads to grilled meats. Buy it [here](http://domainela.com/shop/nv-lini-910-lambrusco-rosso-labrusca).
items.seoDescription: All about frizzante and other lightly-sparkling wines.
items.socialDescription: The bottles bubble more than table wines but less than Champagne. And that's delicious.

items.hed: 4 Relatively Impressive Things to Say About Volcanic Wine
items.dek: Sure, wine grown in plain old clay or limestone is perfectly fine. But what about wine that's grown in ancient volcanic soil? It's time to take *terroir* to the next level.
items.body:
"No, seriously—these wines are grown in *actual* volcanic soil."
----------------------------------------------
No, this isn't some marketing gimmick. And yes, we're talking about black, dead-looking soil from active, dormant, or extinct volcanos. "It’s shocking when you see it," says Patrick Cappiello, the wine director at [Pearl & Ash](http://www.pearlandash.com/) in Manhattan. If you can give your friends a sense of what these vineyards look like, the wines will be instantly more interesting. So describe the wine as springing from the scorched Earth like a Phoenix rising from the ashes...or just whip out your phone and show them the photo below.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/5503166ed7d414037b2af1a7]||||||

+++

"This is *terroir* 2.0."
---------------------------------------
Bringing up the concept of *terroir*—a fancy French wine term to describe a wine's "sense of place"—is one of the easiest ways to set off people's bullshit detectors. Plus, as Cappiello points out, "clay and limestone exist all over the world," so wrapping your brain around why the wine grown in Bordeaux's soil is different than the one in Borolo's can be difficult—not to mention boring. But if any *terroir* is going to be interesting, it's the mineral-rich volcanic soil these wines come from—particularly the reds, which are light, elegant, and much less tannic that most. 

"Get a load of the aromatics on this one!"
------------------------------------------
Dip your nose into a glass of wine grown in volcanic soil and the first thing you'll notice is how much *more* you smell than your run-of-the-mill red or white wine. You're not overthinking it: "The wines are much more aromatic as a result of the mineral content in the soil," explains Cappiello. "The plants are just happier plants." Score extra points by dropping wine terminology like "expressive aromatics," "fresh," and "bright." 

"It's all about the volcanic wines from Sicily"
----------------------------------------------------
There's wine grown in volcanic soil all over the world—Oregon's Willamette Valley and Napa Valley are two sites in the United States. But, for Cappiello, the wines grown on Mount Etna in Sicily are the best examples. "The producers there really capture it," says Cappiello. "A new crew of young producers like Arianna Occhipinti have started making wine there that are so beautiful." If you're looking for a starting point with these wines, look for a bottle from Mount Etna. 

##3 Bottles to Buy##

__2009 Sky Vineyards Zinfandel - $35__ Made from grapes harvested at 2100 feet in California's Mayacamas mountain range.  Buy it [here](http://www.skyvineyards.com/sky/store/). 

__2013 Azienda Agricola Arianna Occhipinti SP68 - $24__ Arianna Occhipinti is a young rock star of the Sicilian wine making set. The SP68 is Occhipinti's entry-level bottle is a great place to start—it's bright, smells like cherries, and does well slightly chilled. Buy it [here](https://www.wineworksonline.com/wines/Occhipinti-Sp68-Terre-Siciliane-Rosso-2013-w5556519rr). 

__2013 Terre Nere Etna Rosso - $18__ An excellent everyday-drinking wine from Mount Etna. Elegant, light, and perfect for warmer weather. Buy it [here](http://www.garyswine.com/fine_wine/italy/11874.html).
items.seoTitle: Everything You Need to Know About Volcanic Wines
items.seoDescription: How to drink, buy, and talk about wines grown in volcanic soil.
items.socialDescription: Sure, wine grown in plain old clay or limestone is perfectly fine. But what about wine that's grown in ancient volcanic soil?

items.hed: 4 Relatively Impressive Things to Say About Oregon Pinot Noir
items.dek: There's a reason why they call Willamette Valley the Burgundy of America.
items.promoHed: How to Find the Best Pinot Noir in the Country
items.body:
"California pinot noir? Pssshhhtt."
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Drive an hour south of Portland—Oregon's capital of culture—and you'll stumble upon the Willamette Valley, one of the country's most exciting wine regions. The Valley produces all sorts of wine—chardonnay, pinot gris, riesling—but is best known for its pinot noir. The pinots produced in Oregon are luscious and mineral-driven. More importantly, they don't shove any fruitiness in your face the way, say, California wines do. (Go ahead, try a Cali pinot next to an Oregon one. The California pinot will probably be full of  black cherry, raspberry, and cranberry flavors; the Oregon pinot will taste earthy.)

[#package: /packages/551571856ec924e9311cc101]||||||

"Willamette is the Burgundy of America"
-----------------------------------------------------------
"Earthy" is a term (of endearment!) often applied to pinot noir from France's Burgundy region—which, by the way, is the gold standard of all the pinot noir on Earth. How do Oregon wines taste so much like Burgundy's? It's all thanks to the climates of the two wine-producing regions being incredibly similar. Both are defined by their year-round mild conditions, where winters are cool and wet and summers are warm and dry. Neither places get too warm (the temperature inches above the unfriendly wine growing mark of 90 °F only a few days each year), which is an environment where Pinot Noir thrives.

"You can pair this stuff with anything. *Anything.*"
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Pinot noir is a great in-between wine when it comes to food. It's light—but not too light. It's complex—but not so overly showy that it demands the attention of everyone at the table. It can pair with fish like salmon or halibut without overpowering them, yet also stand up to foods as rich and gloriously fatty as a juicy Peking duck. 

"I'm a Dundee Hills Man Myself, But I Can Get Down With Other Sub-Appellations"
------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Willamette Valley is divided into six major growing areas, or sub-appellations. Get to know this list—memorize it, even, for bonus points with your in-the-know friends—so you know what to look for when you head to your local wine store to buy that next batch of Willamette Valley Pinot Noir: Eola-Amity Hills, McMinnville, Chehalem Mountains, Ribbon Ridge, Yamhill-Carlton District, and Dundee Hills.

3 Bottles to Buy
----------------
__2012 Soter North Valley Pinot Noir - $28__  Soter consistently tops wine snob lists for the best Pinot Noir in Oregon. But most of their wines are *expensive*—their flagship pinot sells for $150. This North Valley is an entry-level bottle, but it's a good indicator of why Soter is so beloved. Buy it [here](http://www.wineanthology.com/p-12592-soter-north-valley-pinot-noir-2012.aspx). 

__2013 Maison L'Envoye Two Messengers Pinot Noir - $27__ Crisp and fruity with a hint of meaty spice: This is the pinot noir we want to drink every day. Buy it [here](http://domainela.com/shop/2013-maison-l-envoye-two-messengers-pinot-noir). 

__2013 Bow & Arrow Rhinestones - $25__ Winemaker Scott Frank is a star in the Willamette Valley. He makes wines that are full of earthy funk, but not too off the beaten path to be enjoy with family and friends over a backyard cookout. Buy it [here](http://domainela.com/shop/2013-bow-and-arrow-rhinestones).
items.seoTitle: Willamette Valley Pinot Noir Wine Buying Guide
items.socialTitle: 4 Relatively Impressive Things to Say About Pinot Noir from Oregon's Willamette Valley
items.seoDescription: Which Oregon pinot noirs to buy—and why.

items.hed: 4 Relatively Impressive Things to Say about Loire Valley White Wines
items.dek: Think all delicious, French white wine is out of reach? Nope.
items.promoHed: Cheap White Wines to Drink This Spring
items.body:
"The Loire is *the* Place for Awesome, Cheap White Wine"
------------------------------------------------------
Spring's here, so it's time to put down those bottles of [New California red wines](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/new-cheap-california-wines-article) (and—even if only for a second—[all that delicious Beaujolais](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/5-talking-points-beaujolais-french-red-wine-article)) and start basking in the glory of white wine yet again. And for that, there's no better place to look than France's Loire Valley. Bright, fresh and low in alcohol, Loire whites are ideal for day-drinking. But they also have an economic advantage: "It’s one of the very few wine regions in France that still has exceptional value," says Laura Maniec, co-owner of [Corkbuzz](https://corkbuzz.com/), a wine bar and education space in Manhattan. "Even the best of the best are cheaper than a basic, entry-level Burgundy or Bordeaux." What does she mean by cheap? Under $20. Sometimes *way* under.

[#package: /packages/551571856ec924e9311cc101]||||||

"The Valley's Biggest Advantage? Variety, Variety Variety"
-------------------------
Clocking in at over 300 square miles, the Loire Valley is *massive* and composed of many different wine-producing regions. "Even if we’re setting aside the fact that the Loire makes rosé, sparkling wine, red wine, and dessert wine, and just focus on the whites," says Maniec, "there are still so many styles of wine." Unlike most other places that produce wine around the world, you've probably heard of a lot of the Loire's regions. Sancerre, Vouvray, Chinon, and Muscadet are the most notable, with mass-market examples available on many grocery and liquor store shelves across the country. What does all this variety and selection mean? There's a Loire wine for everybody: "There's a little bit of esoteric, a bit of approachable, and a bit of tried and true." 

"I've Really Been on a Muscadet Kick Lately"
------------------------------------------
Chance are you've encountered the wines of Muscadet at one point or another. It was probably served alongside freshly-shucked oysters, and it was probably, you know, *fine.* Bright, cheery, and cheap, the bottle was probably put on a block of ice and served so cold that nothing really mattered—you might even call it the Pilsner of Wine. But not all Muscadet is so thin, watery and boring. In fact, top producers like Domaine de l’Ecu, Andre-Michel Brégeon, and Domaine Landron produce incredible wines that full of flavor, texture, and a hint of sparkly effervescence (more on that [here](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/slightly-sparkling-wines-frizzante-article)). And they rarely crack the $20 mark. 

"You Don't Have to Drink the Stuff *Right Away*, Guys"
------------------------------------------------------
It's not easy to resist a bottle of wine that's so seasonally appropriate and drinkable. But Maniec points out that Loire whites are excellent candidates for aging. "They're white wines that keep their youth," she explains. But, with age, they take on a mellow softness and slight brininess that help them develop into slightly more complex bottles of wine. So, get crazy and buy two bottles—one to drink immediately and one to store in a dark, cool place until Spring/Summer 2020. Actually, what the hell, these bottles are $15—may as well buy three.

3 Bottles to Buy
----------------
__2009 Domaine de l'Ecu "Expression de Granite" - $21__ The Muscadet you buy to prove to people that Muscadet can transcend the cheery but boring wines of oyster bars. Buy it [here](http://www.artisanwinedepot.com/Domaine_de_l_Ecu_Expression_de_Granite_Muscadet_p/lecumuscadetgranite09-w.htm). 

__2012 Tessier Cour-Cheverny - $20__ This white from the itsy-bitsy appellation of Cour-Cheverny is made by Phillippe Tessier, one of the rock star producers in the Loire. Buy it [here](http://www.astorwines.com/SearchResultsSingle.aspx?p=1&search=31542&searchtype=Contains). 

__2013 Vincent Caille Gros-Plant - $13__ That inexpensive, extremely drinkable white wine you buy a case of for the summer? This is that wine. Buy it [here](http://domainela.com/2013-vincent-caille-gros-plant).
items.seoTitle: Cheap White Wines to Drink This Spring
items.seoDescription: Think all delicious, French white wine is out of reach? Nope.

items.hed: Four Relatively Impressive Things to Say About the New California Wine Movement
items.dek: Think California wine is all about the jammy reds? Think again.
items.body:
"To Understand California Wine's Present, You Gotta Understand Its Past"
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
And that past is this: In the 1970s, California wines made a breakthrough when a few California wines beat out French wines at a competition in what became known as the [Judgement of Paris](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judgment_of_Paris_%28wine%29). After that, two things happened: 1. A lot of brands grew to enormous sizes and started producing low-quality wines. 2. About a decade later, a new group of young winemakers decided they needed to re-establish the state's prestige, which led to respected but incredibly expensive "cult" wines. Both of these phenomena led to some wariness on the part of serious wine drinkers. "When I moved to California 15 years ago I was having existential issues with California wines," recalls Jon Bonne, a wine writer and author of [*The New California Wine*](http://www.amazon.com/The-New-California-Wine-Revolution/dp/1607743000). "They didn’t go very well with food and they were mostly interested in being self-important." 

But that's the past, man. California wine has now finally entered the future.

"Those Big, Jammy Reds? They're gone."
-------------------------------------------------
One of the hallmarks of the older generation of California wines? "Big," "jammy" red wines. These wines were high in alcohol and possessed a level of fruity flavor that smacked you in the face when you drank it. Luckily, these fruit-bombs aren't nearly as prevalent as they once were. "We are now entering a new golden era in California wine," says Bonne. "These new wines being produced don't taste outsized." That's thanks to the newest crop of California wine makers, most of whom are under 45, that are making easy-drinking wines—the type of bottles you'd put on the table during a meal. (A few wine terms to drop when describing these wines: "Fresh" and "sunny fruit." Because there *is* fruit—it's just *fresh* fruit. 

"California's Wine Growing Climate is *So* Diverse"
------------------------------------------------------------------------
We tend to pigeonhole all of California as having one style of wine. But the truth is the state is no one-trick pony when it comes to soil-type and climate. "If you think about the size of California and the diversity of soils and climates, it’s as diverse, or even more so, than France," says Bonne. And some of these new Cali wines aren't just from the northern part of the state (Sonoma, Mendocino, Napa Valley), but also Santa Barbara and even San Diego. 

"California Wine is Cheap now! Kind of."
-------------------------------------------------
One of the biggest issues with the "cult" wines of the 90s were their extremely high prices. This new class of California wine maker is producing wine with consumers in mind, aiming to make less expensive wines. "One thing people have done is to focus on some forgotten grape varietals that were essentially being sold to make cheap jug wine," says Bonne. Carignan and chenin blanc are a couple of the lesser-known grapes winemakers are using to get the price of wine down without sacrificing quality. But no matter what grapes are used, "the twelve-dollar bottle may never happen," explains Bonne. "The simple cost of labor and land that you have to account for in California is just really high." That's okay—California wines are getting to be worth the money again. 

3 Bottles to Buy
----------------

__2013 Sandhi Santa Barbara Chardonnay - $33__ The price tag may be a bit high, but this entry-level option from Sandhi is worth the splurge. You'll get a classic example of what *new* Chardonnay looks like: No buttery oak, all fresh, juicy purity. Buy it [here](http://shop.sandhiwines.com/product/2013-Santa-Barbara-County-Chardonnay).

__2014 Broc Cellars White Zinfandel - $24__ Chris Brockway is one of the stars of this new California wine movement. His white zinefindel is a great place to start—sunny, fresh, and endlessly drinkable. Buy it [here](http://www.broccellars.com/store/#!/2014-White-Zinfandel/p/46821967/category=0).

 __2012 Vesper Vineyards Rosé__ - $21 Yes, there's incredible rosé being produced in San Diego by a husband-and-wife team. Buy it [here](http://www.vespervineyards.com/product/2012-McCormick-Ranch-Rose).
items.seoDescription: A new class of California winemakers are making better, cheaper wines.
items.socialTitle: How California Wine Got Good Again
items.socialDescription: You can thank a group of new, young winemakers for that.

items.hed: Five Relatively Impressive Things to Say About Beaujolais
items.dek: These easy-drinking bottles from France are cheap, versatile and—therefore—what you should be bringing to every dinner party. In fact, they're so good, people are bound to ask you about it. This is what to say when they do.
items.promoHed: 5 Dinner Party Talking Points for Beaujolais Wine
items.seoTitle: 5 Dinner Party Talking Points for Beaujolais Red Wine
items.socialTitle: Beaujolais: The Red Wine for People Who Don't Like Red Wine
items.body:
"These tannins are soft as *silk*."
---------------------------------------------------------------

Tannins are the naturally occurring compounds that make some red wines taste bitter and astringent and make your tongue dry out. The reason you care? Beaujolais (pronounced *Boh-zhoh-lay*, by the way), made from gamay grapes, is low in them. So instead of a mouthful of pucker, "you'll get a lot of red berry fruit and a nice bit of subtle acidity," explains Jill Bernheimer, owner of LA specialty wine shop [Domaine LA](http://domainela.com/). 


"Beaujolais Nouveau has totally made a comeback."
-----------------------------------------------------

The Beaujolais region is best known for Beaujolais Nouveau, which is released on the third Thursday of every November and is the always the first red wine of the season. In the 80s and 90s, people were crazy for the stuff. But most of it was swill. "There were some weird aromatic things going on there that ended up making the wine smell like sweet banana gum," explains Bernheimer. 

But that was then. Today, many of the producers that make great non-Nouveau Beaujolais (more on them in a second) also make and distribute the celebratory Nouveau bottling. And unlike the Nouveau of 30 years ago, it's dangerously drinkable. 

"You wouldn't believe the deal I got on this bottle."
-------------------------------------------

Anybody can shell out a few hundred bucks and nab a top-shelf Burgundy and Barolo. The real win for wine dorks? Great bottles that are a steal. And that's exactly what some Beaujolais is. Look for Cru Beaujolais, which "is anywhere from $20 to $40 for the very top end," says Bernheimer. And we're not talking about dozens of bottles that taste, look, and drink exactly the same here. There's a variety of styles to explore within the region, all of which you can try without taking out a second mortgage on the house.    

"This would be great with [insert literally any food here]"
------------------------------------------------

"Versatility is Beaujolais' greatest strength," says Bernheimer. On one hand, it's a great "session wine," the type of thing you can glug down without much thought and over a long period of time because of its relatively low alcohol levels. But Bernheimer also points out that the wine has enough acidity to make it an ideal food-drinking wine. So go ahead and say that Beaujolais goes well with ham sandwiches, or pulled pork, or roasted sunchokes. Because it does.

"Okay, Fine, I'll Name the 10 Crus of Beaujolais"
-------------------------------------------------

Here they are! St-Amour, Juliénas, Chénas, Moulin-a-Vent, Fleurie, Chiroubles, Morgon, Régnié, Brouilly, and Côte de Brouilly.

(Something to know if you're going to memorize this list: "Crus" are the [top wine-producing villages in the Beaujolais region](http://flatiron-wines.com/blog/a-guide-to-the-10-crus-of-beaujolais). Sometimes the name of the village (i.e. Fleurie) is on the label instead of the word "Beaujolais." That's a good thing. It's high class.)


3 bottles to buy
-------------------------------------

These are the bottles of Beaujolais that Bernheimer finds herself going to back to over and over again.

*2013 Domaine Dupeuble Beaujolais* - $17
"A lighter, fruity and approachable bottle that showcases the versatility of the gamay grape." 
Buy it [here](http://www.klwines.com/detail.asp?sku=1145507)

*2013 Terres Dorées l'Ancien Beaujolais* - $18
"Huge bang for your buck in this rustic but substantial bottle." 
Buy it [here](http://domainela.com/shop/2013-terres-dorees-beaujolais-l-ancien)

*2013 Marcel Lapierre Morgon* - $32
"An elegant and sophisticated bottle."
Buy it [here](http://domainela.com/shop/2013-marcel-lapierre-morgon)
items.seoDescription: These easy-drinking bottles from France are cheap, versatile and—therefore—what you should be bringing to every dinner party. In fact, they're so good, people are bound to ask you about it. This is what to say when they do.
